bibl.title: Interview with Frank R. McCoy, by Philip Showalter Hench, February 19, 1948

div1.p: McCoy, aide to Governor-General Leonard Wood during the yellow fever experiments, comments on Wood's dismissal of the importance of Finlay's mosquito work, Wood's intervention with Surgeon General Sternberg to keep Reed's work going, and the location and arrangement of Wood's offices. McCoy stresses Wood's strong support of Reed and his work.

div1.head: Interview with Frank R. McCoy, by Philip Showalter Hench, February 19, 1948
div1.p:
Interview with Gen. Frank McCoy, Washington, D C
Feb 19, 1948 by P. S. Hench

Gen McCoy was a lieutenant in the Spanish-American War and became
Gen. Wood's aide in May 1900. Wood had became Governor-General
in Dec 1899.

list.item:
1 I asked Gen McCoy if he recollected when or if Finlay saw Gen Wood
(see Eric F Wood's book - p 196 bottom - 197 top). It was Gen. McCoy's
recollection that Dr Finlay actually did call on Wood almost as soon
as Wood arrived to become Gov-Gen. Wood had had a high
regard for Finlay as a man and as a physician but not as a
scientist. Indeed Wood believed that Finlay's work had practically
resulted in disproving (not proving) his (Finlay's) theory.

item.p:
2 according to Hagedorn (Biography of Leonard Wood - Harper's 1931,
vol 1 p 332) “Twice indeed the investigation (Reed's) had nearly
been stopped by orders from the Surgeon General who needed
his doctors and felt that too much time had already been
wasted but each time Wood had intervened and saved the
Commission” (McCoy from the S. G; 1929).

Gen McCoy has the distinct remembrance that Gen. Sternberg
tried at least twice to recall Reed (in addition to the one time
Reed was recalled to finish the Typhoid Fever Investigation). McCoy
believes Sternberg tried to recall Reed early in the summer of 1900,
(apparently earlier than Reed's return in early Aug 1900). on this
occasion, Wood interviewed at the instigation of Reed, Wood
intervened e the S. G. (probably by letter or telegram - Wood to
Sternberg, possibly of a more or less personal letter as Wood was
corresponding almost daily with various Washington people).
In this case Reed's recall was stopped.

McCoy believes recalls that later (perhaps Sept-Oct 1900)
in the summer (sometime in Oct?) the S G again wanted Reed to
return to Wash for some “routine project.” This time Wood had
to intervene with Secr. of War Root to get the S. G. to let Reed
alone. Wood had become much impressed with Reed's work
and became annoyed that Sternberg should want to recall
Reed for routine duties.

list.item:
3 McCoy says Hagedorn lives in New York City. (Hermann Hagedorn,
Roosevelt Memorial assoc., Roosevelt House, 28 E 20th St., New York, 3, N Y.)

item.p:
4 McCoy located Gen Wood's offices as comprising one large room
on the south front of the bldg; second floor, with 3 large front
windows (as formerly located for me of Gen Kean & as marked with
an arrow in old photo (S C 113632). Wood's desk was in the
center of the room with Wood's chair facing (west) away from the
windows (Wood's back to the center of the 3 window's

(Ask Gen McCoy to draw rough plan of this 2nd floor front)
When the Cuban's renovated the building between the first &
second U. S. Interventions they removed the stucco (seen in 1900
photos) & exposed the old underlying stone walls (as seen in
recent current National Geographic Magazine photos of the old
bldg (now the City Hall, Havana).

In Gen. Wood's tenure of the office there were no actual
doors (in the door spaces or passage ways) between Wood's
office & the halls. The door shown in the army photo
(S C 107499) (showing Gen Magoun in Wood's old office)
was not there in Wood's day. (See Wood photo - Hagedorn p 171;) in
this photo Wood faces the light, apparently the windows)

5 I discussed with Gen McCoy the item in Hagedorn
(vol 1, p 281) where Wood is credited with having urged
the S. G (Sternberg) to appoint the Yellow Fever Commission,
Gen McCoy believes that Wood undoubtedly did this & that he
also suggested to Sternberg who should be on the Board.
According to McCoy the Surgeon Generals part in the formation
(and support) of the Yellow Fever Board was rather passive
& secondary, not active & primary. McCoy believes that
Wood's chief role in the formation of the Y. F board can be
documented by reviewing Wood's file of personal letters
& Woods diary, all of which were Kept of Wood &
left to the Congressional Library. They constitute “The Wood
Papers” & are a special collection available only to accredited
historians & researchers. Gen McCoy promised to ask
the permission of Gen. Wood's daughter (Louise Wood) for me
(3
to study these data, which are under control of Dr Sions att,
Curator of these data (Di. St. George to Sionesat, Chief of Manuscripts, Division,
Reference Dept, Library of Congress.).

The rest of Wood's voluminous records would have been filed
with the War Dept under “Records of the Military Governor of
Cuba” (They should be in the Archives Bldg).

list.item:
6 Gen McCoy was not at the Dec 22, 1900 banquet for
Finlay at Delmonico's restaurant, did not
know the restaurant & believed that it was not one of the
prominent restaurants,

7 The photo labelled “Wood in his office in Havana”
in Holmes' “Life of Leonard Wood. (Double day, Page & Co 1920)
p 116 is not of Wood's office in Havana but of Wood's
office in Santiago & the other man in the photo is
Ramon Mendoza (rank?) who was then Wood's aide in
Santiago.

8 Gen McCoy urges me to look up John Kendrick Bang's
book “Uncle Sam, Trustee” which contains much on Wood.

9 Mr. V. Swann, a clerk in Wood's office in 1900 still live
in Havana & can be reached through Ing. (Engineer) Jose
Garcia Inerantz, Tel U 7445, Apartado, P. O. Box
404, Havana, Cuba.

10. The Maestranza (“arsenal” in Spanish) was in Spanish days
an artillery Depot. In this old building Gorgas had his
headquarters, also here were the apartments (quarters) of
the Headquarters Staff. (Wood's Staff & aides) - Scott, chief of
Staff; Bliss, Gorgas, Black, Greble, McCoy. They had their
own mess there also.

item.p:
11) according to Gen McCoy Gen. Wood left Havana for the U S. early in
the summer of 1900. Reed and his colleagues often came in to Woods office
for one thing or another, chiefly for money. Wood had told Lt. McCoy, his
aide, that Reed was to have whatever he needed. But when Reed asked
for this & that amount of money, McCoy became disturbed. He (McCoy)
was trying hard to keep track of all expenses, cut out
useless expenditures etc & he wasnt certain just how much
financial assistance Wood really meant Reed to have.
on one early occasion (date?) when Reed wanted money
McCoy temporarily refused, & wrote Wood (telegraphed?)
Wood for clarification of his (Wood's) attitude toward Reed's
expenses. Back came Wood's order to give Reed all he
wanted. Thereaf Thereafter McCoy did so. (McCoy was, of
course, not a player & didnt appreciate the significance
of Reed's work).

According to McCoy, Gen Wood was increasingly impressed
of Reed's results & never let anything interfere with the its
successful accomplishment. As matters progressed Wood
would repeatedly evaluate Reeds work as of the very
greatest importance.

On Oct 9, 1900 which was Wood's birthday Wood forgot it
was his birthday, His wife had left Havana for the U. S &
Wood was “alone” in Havana. At the end of the day when the
offices were closed & the aides & staff had left Wood suddenly
remembered it was his birthday & called his staff & aides
about 5 P M & asked them to dine with him at 8 P M
to celebrate help him celebrate. But when they all arrived
(only men?) Wood was elated. After the dinner had progressed
he said to his staff something as follows: “I've been in
communication with Dr Reed. My birthday gives me an excuse to
gather you together with me here & I want to announce the tremendous
importance of Reed's discoveries. I want you all to know of them
& their significance. This is a most important thing. . --”

Then Wood went on to tell them that Reed believed the
(5
cause of Y. F had actually been discovered, --- etc.
(For further details of this story see Hagedorn vol 1, p 326).
Ask Gen McCoy for further details. He believes that Gen (Maj) Kean
was at this birthday dinner (check with Gen Kean).

list.item:
12.) Gen. McCoy's office is at 2516 Massachusetts Ave.,
(Old Japanese Embassy). He is chief chairman of the
Far Eastern Commission. (Telephone Extension 3141)
Miss Porter is his secretary.
